It's called "opponent process theory." They do this in the US. Anthony Morrison is one. The call center will call people who bought his book on a late-night ad about how to get rich quick online. Usually the elderly, Then the person will go through a whole process of building the person up with their goals and what they could achieve online making money, once they are pumped, they then go through all the debt and reasons WHY they aren't rich yet. Oh, but wait! What if that could be turned around? HAHA! then the person finds out where they have money and what the "downpayment" will be for the EXCLUSIVE one on one coaching with an EXPERT!  All of it is really bogus... some might make money. but its more about just getting as much as you can to get someone signed up. I actually worked at one of his call centers, until I realized the scam. Needless to say, that business is permanently closed now. So, it's not just foreign scammers!! There are some US ones too!!

Hiya, in the UK, we usually get a call which goes like this, with no pause for breath. "Hi, is that Mrs White my name is Claire Smith and I just want to do a quick survey just 3 or 4 questions  it won't take much time maybe 3 minutes is this OK? This is all spoken really quickly, not given you any time to answer, even if you try and interrupt them.  When they ask  if that's OK, I ask if that is the first question.  They then say "no, we are doing a quick survey and want to as you some quick questions is that OK? So I repeat "So THAT is the first question?". They then ask "Can you please listen to me, the survey is very quick and only 3 questions is that OK?" So I say "Those must be the 3 questions, thanks for calling, bye" and put the phone down. Someone told me that these "survey scams" are to either get personal details or get you to say "Yes", so then they can edit a call saying any of the usual scams, but put your recorded voice saying yes to the new questions. Any idea if either of these are right, or is it something else? Not had any calls in the UK since the AntiScam centre opened!!

This sounds silly but works to confuse, distract the scammer. Answers to their questions with silly, bizarre things, e.g. can you cook fish in a dishwasher?, I just stabbed my husband/wife & blood is on my white carpet, how can I get it out?, my kids just jumped out of their bubble bath & are running down the sidewalk can you help me?, or any other strange things you can think of. Use the appropriate tone of voice for what you say. You'll throw them off their game, they won't know what hit them. Another trick is to use one word answers, e.g. yes, really, no, now, why, how, when, what, where, seriously, super, fabulous. . . We usually get recordings & they do not answer back.

Scammers cannot turn your computer on if it is NOT CONNECTED TO THE INTERNET. So if you think you have been scammed, unplug your router or click on the internet icon in your toolbar and click on disconnect there when you are not using it or leave the house. Unplugging your router is easier and quicker and your computer is safe from any and all hackers like this. If you really want to discourage them don't use your computer for about 2 weeks or more. The software that was downloaded onto your computer may have a routine in it that alerts them when you turn on your computer. These guys are busy and I don't think they will monitor you for long and get tired of the extra effort they have to put into scamming you.

Salt Lake Sector 5 , Kolkata, West Bengal is the hub of scammer in India. Mostly Bengali unemployed youth , sometimes high school and college dropout. They operate from offices in big commercial building with illegal licenses and recruit and pay young recruits around Rs12000 to Rs 15000. They operate round the clock with morning and night shifts depending on which country they want to scam. The new recruits both boys and girls are trained to talk in American and British accent and given a written script. If a recruit has previous call center experience they get a better salary and given the role of Team Leaders. Most of these call centers are fly by night operators as they know once exposed they have to dismantle and go underground. These scammers always come back in a new location with new recruits once the law enforcement stops looking for them. Many such call centers have been raided and closed down but the easy money involved always brings them back. Youtube along with scam busters like you have created a big difference and awareness about these scammers. They now find difficult to scam easily but still some innocent gets caught.

One of the greatest things I ever did was to save an old guy gettign scammed out of Â£5000. So Im a taxi driver, and I was sent to pick a old guy in Brighton England. He got into my car and started telling me his story. His landlord has gone on Holiday, and these "Builders" turned up today saying thye had to do soem work on the house thathis landlord had asked them to do. But the Landlord had nto paid them the money, and that he needed to go to his bank and withdraw the money to pay them. His landlord was not able to be reached as he was on a flight. It just didnt seem rtight to me, but the old guy was determined to go to the bank. On the Journey to the bank, I convinced him to get the bank to call the police, as he was now scared of going back home to where these builders are, he was also worried about wasting police time if the story was genuine. I told him, the police would not be concerend about you wasting their time if their story was genuine, but they would be more concerened if it was not.  Anyway I dropped the guy off and thats the last I heard for about a week. Then I get a call from the police, and they asked if I remember the guy I took to the bank, my stomach fell and thought he had been scammed, but no, he had taken my advice and got the bank to call them, and the police asked what made me give them that advice, and I toild them I had been watching this Youtube channel about people being scammed (Scammer Payback) and that I just thought it didint sound right and you (the police) wouldnt mind being called out if a the builders story was was genuine but would be worse if it wasnt and he lost a load of money, they said I was correct, it was a scam, and they had 3 people in custody, and if I could attend and ID parade as I could identify at least one of them. Just want to run this by all the techy people in here, about tech support scams, whats the scope of something like this.  What if a service was implemented at OS level? The service would check if there are any active remote connections to the machine, being either via OS built-in or third part software.  The browser would then perform checks on that service, if the service is stopped, the browser can block all website sing-in pages.  This would ensure security even if the scammer gains remote access and stops the service.  Lastly the FINANCIAL institutions would perform secondary checks on the browser to verify if the service checks were successful. In the event the machine has any active remote connection then it can block all online banking access. OTHER websites wouldnâ€™t have to perform this check to allow verified tech support and admins to do their actual job. In no way is this even close to a solution but Tech Giants have the means to tweak and fine tune the general idea.  And as I type this, I already see a flaw, third party/open source browsers. I guess financial institution can restrict online banking access to certified/verified browsers only.    Similar protocols can be implemented on phones as well.  I would say very few of the scammers actually have the in-depth knowledge of software and networking to be able manipulate or exploit something like this, so well over half would outright just be stopped in their scams but even if we say half or close to half, it would still be a win.  Technology has advanced a lot over the last decade and to see tech scam being a million-dollar industry just seems ridiculous. The companies out there that turn a blind eye to their software or services being utilized by scammers are either incompetent to fix their own software or just selfish enough to ride the free marketing train as hardworking YouTube scam baiters try educate the general population on tools used by those scammers.

One thing I have found is that the the scammers will say that they are from all kinds of companies. One day they may say that they are from Microsoft, the next day they will say that they are from Amazon and most likely it will be the same person. One time I had a call from a guy that said he was from Microsoft and that I had a problem with my computer. The dead giveaway that this guy was a scammer is when he said he was from Microsoft. Microsoft wonâ€™t be calling people to fix computers. A few months later the same guy called again and said that he from some other company. I recognized the voice of the guy and told him he might as well give up calling me and that I know itâ€™s a scam. I have an answering machine on my home phone (landline) and have stopped answering the phone. I let the answering machine take the call. What I have found is that robocalls and scammers will hang up when the answering machine kicks in. If itâ€™s  important the person will leave a message.

We both pretended to be old people and agreed that yes, it was running slow, it takes a long time to start.... Here we go ğŸ˜ Told scammer yes, just turned on pc. After about an hour he kept asking if it was on yet, said no, it takes a very long time. After 3 hours of him asking if it was on yet and us saying not yet(still pretending to be old people not too worried about the speed of "calculator" coz it always goes slow, sometimes takes a day to turn it on) then scammer hangs up. He rings back 15 mins later and asks if PC is booted up yet. We say "no, we turned it off coz you hung up, we thought you fixed it" Scammer says turn it back on. Again for 3 hours he holds on, us saying it is very slow and not yet ready to login. He hangs up. Rings back, we say sorry, turned it off... You get the idea. We had this scamming idiot going for 3 days straight. To the scammer's credit, he never got angry or overly pushy.  BTW, had full protection plus thorough knowledge of coding as we mechatronics engineers also running an eBay business. After 3 days, 10+ hours/day he hung up saying he'd call the next day. I was wondering why this scam has become so rare in my country, with banking they have either 2 factor authentication with a custom bank made device or with the banking app on the phone. Making the whole "save password to browser" set practically impossible. On top of that banking through the banking app is far more popular than through a site, and changing detail in a banking app is much hard than a site.  Granted we do have quite a lot of other scams that never seem to pop up in the US. The type we often have here is the "I changed my number, I need money" scam, where scammers claim to be a relative or friend in need that recently changed numbers. Or they try to get you to login on a fake banking site, and pass all that data, including the 2 factor, directly to a real login and buy shit with it or just straight up transfer it out. And texting people claiming they need to send an X amount to avoid tax issues. All except for the second have a pretty limited profit margin compared to US scams it seems.

_"There's a sucker born every minute."_  ~P.T. Barnum Social engineering scams have existed for all of man's days walking this earth - the slick-politician who wants your vote, the covered wagon rolling into a dusty town selling magical elixirs, the female showing cleavage to the cop writing out her ticket, even the garden serpent - all use social engineering to get what they want from their target.  We should expect that to NEVER change, it's a fools errand to think anything will shutdown any of these scams, that's just the reality of the situation.  And it's accurate for Pierogi to point out spreading the word as the best defense.  I have sent countless emails to local government, asking them to consider creating national PSA's, blasted across television, newspaper, social media et al, alerting citizens of these scams.  Afterall, it's only the citizens who don't know about these scams, who become victims.  I urge everyone to call/email/write letters to your local government, even NGO's and charities, asking them to please create PSA's.  My household is of retirement age, and all of our Social Security mail comes with a nice big warning printed across the back of the envelope, which is a great start - we just need that same warning plastered across the airwaves.  Unfortunately, I have not received anything other than a routine "formed" response, probably because there aren't many citizens demanding a resolution.  It doesn't take a lot of time once you've crafted a letter/email, as you can send the same wording asking for PSA-blast, to everyone on your list.  I even printed-up a flyer and stuck it to my community's mailbox area, hopefully at least everyone in my neighborhood knows what's up!  Good luck!

Some bank scammers managed to call off of my bank's phone number once, and tried to ask me for my username and account number and other personal information. Since it was suspicious, I played with them for a while. I said, "OK, but then you should have access to the database as a representative."  They seemed confused and there was someone in the background coaching them. I heard the coach, so I played up my IT knowledge more and said things like, "Oh, you don't have access to the front end of the database, then you should call the IT department and ask them to access it by mySQL if it's broken like you claim. Hey, do you know PHP? Or do you think it's written in ASP? (I already knew which one it was written in, but pretty much testing the caller)" "Do you need the phone number for the IT department [of the bank] since your database is broken? [Gives bank phone number for IT department.]" And so on...  I spooked them with IT knowledge, then called my bank, got the way to report the scammers. The bank about a week later issued a general notice that they'd never ask for ssn's, passwords, etc. About a week after that, they had everyone change their usernames, but being wary, I tested the caller trying to change my username to make sure it wasn't a scam by asking them the same questions the scammers in the past asked me (Do you need my ssn, bank account number, etc), and then verified it was a legit caller. I'm guessing they found the scammers eventually, since I gave them as much information I could about the call center. (These were not of Indian descent, BTW and were stupid enough to use their real voices.) The bank tightened security and made it so it was harder to find the usernames on the accounts after that.  Another scammer called recently and I delayed them by talking about the food I'd ordered, etc. "Do you want a rebate?" "Uhhh... are you the delivery person for my food?" "No." So I delayed them a bit about the food... asked if they were a scammer, etc.

In 2012 I was working in a Walgreens. We had an older  gentleman who kept coming in buying gift cards. Shortly there after we got the policy come down that we had to start asking questions when large amounts of gift cards were purchased by a single customer. So when he came in, I asked him why he was buying these cards. He told me that the FBI was demanding payment out of him and that they'd contacted him by phone. I was the one who had to tell him that he was being robbed. He looked so defeated.  It disgusts me that almost a decade later, not only is this crap still happening, but it seems like it's a growth industry. The government needs to wake up. These criminal networks need to get shut down.  EDIT: I just want to make it clear, from what I gathered out of what he eventually told me, it had seemed like they were running a different scam on him, but he was refusing to pay believing it to be a scam. So they were pretending to be the FBI to put pressure on him.
